data.title: Aster Gardens holds official grand opening
data.meta_description: Although it opened its doors last year, Aster Gardens held its grand opening this past month.
data.text:
Article content

We apologize, but this video has failed to load.

tap here to see other videos from our team.

Aster Gardens holds official grand opening Back to video

The 157-suite fully independent living seniors residence, which is located at 7 Brower Drive, took two years of development, but offers a contemporary take towards retirement.

The grand opening, which was held on Monday, June 27, had been postponed last year due to COVID restrictions. The grand opening celebration was a resounding success, according to the managing company, as more than 300 people attended.

Mayor Rod Frank, Ward 2 Coun. Dave Anderson, Ward 4 Coun. Bill Tonita and Ward 1 Coun. Robert Parks all attended the grand opening.

“Thanks to Optima Living for investing in our community, and providing an important piece of the puzzle in seniors housing,” the mayor said.

Parks said he was excited to see the facility hold its grand opening.

Article content

“Always good to see the newest addition to Strathcona County’s seniors housing,” Parks said. “Operated by OptimaLiving, Aster Gardens in Sherwood Park contains 153 units, including 24 memory care spaces.”

Tonita added that it was wonderful to see a new addition to seniors housing in Sherwood Park.

Local MLAs Nate Glubish and Jordan Walker were also in attendance.

The event also featured live music from the local band Dahlia and the Villains.

“We are not just following the rulebook, we are rewriting the book in seniors’ care,” explained Karen Fitzgerald, Aster Gardens general manager.

The grand opening featured tours of the building, the live music and food trucks.

Optima Living and Pangman Development Corporation, as well as the founders of Synergy Wellness Centre, made a $50-million private investment into the facility to make it possible.

Aster Gardens is an active seniors living community designed with residents in mind to provide a place for seniors to live with purpose and enjoy their twilight years.

The building’s design was inspired by the Aster Flower, which is Indigenous to the Strathcona County area, and features seven dining areas, a putting green on the roof, a garden, an art studio, rooftop yoga classes, a library, a spa, a pool, a bistro, a rooftop patio and a pub. The building also features its own theatre for residents.

You can find out more at AsterGardens.ca.
